results.notes:
Several large old fruitbodies present growing from rotting conifer logs (at least one was lodgepole pine), but identifiable as it is one of the most distinctive species around here.
Description:
very large and firm (larger than my hand), with caps usually beginning to break apart; caps white with large, gray-brown to medium brown appressed scales and a few yellow-brown patches in age. Very distinctive for the size and patterning and combination with white gills/spores. Flesh of cap thick and tough, creamy in better conditions and browning in older, more rotted fruitbodies. Margin of cap very thick and either inrolled or nearly so, darker than the caps and usually showing signs of rot. Gills, when present, off-white, with many subgills. Some older patches discolored. Stipes whiter near apex, solid and tough, and with tapered bases, which were much darker in color and beginning to rot. No partial veil, eliminating N. lepideus. Specimens did not have a noticeable odor, but perhaps due to age.
I do have photos, but they are not very helpful.

notes_fields.Macro:
This mature specimen was collected about 30m from a small pond at Pauraque Ridge Farm in northern Bee, Co., Texas. It was near a location where several examples of an Agaricus species were collected earlier this year (see MO402412). Although this is probably the same species, what caught my attention was the highly convex cap of this one in contrast to the mostly flat caps of the mature specimens I had collected previously. This variance could be caused by different sunlight intensity (being later in the spring) or different moisture conditions, or maybe something else.
It was solitary (accept that a younger cap was growing from the same position on the ground). It has dark brown gills and was of an ivory color, both pileus, and stipe. The gills were free. The cap was mostly smooth, but tiny hairs could be seen with a hand lens. The margin of the cap was curled under and more or less smooth. The larger cap margin was not quite a circle measuring 4.6cm long and 4.2cm wide. The stipe (5.5cm long) tapered from 1.3cm where it connected with the cap at 0.8cm to the ground. I did not detect color changes with bruising. An obvious ring was on the stipe but no sign of a volva. Latex was absent. The odor was distinctly like A. bisporus. The stim was cut and observed to be “stuffed.” I noticed a slight yellowing on the inside surface of the cut stipe. Very slight color changes were noticed after the application of 4% KOH (faint yellowing), NH4OH (faint yellowing), and FeSo4 (slightly greenish).
notes_fields.Micro:
I collected spores from the larger cap, prepared a slide stained with KOH, and measured the approximate length and width of 30 examples. The average spore length was 6.89µm (σ 0.42µm) and the average width was 4.93µm (σ 0.27µm).
Okay, call me an overbearing nerd, but I decided to include a link to a video (http://reflectionstexas.com/Spore%20measurement/) of how I am making the spore measurements. I have an inexpensive microscope with a camera port (Amscope ~ $300). Most of the time, I go to the trouble of using the oil emersion lens (1000x) and making the measurements at that magnification. This time, I used 400x and no oil. I have an old Canon Rebel T2i and use a free program called DigiCamControl to take photos with the Rebel and transfer them to my desktop. I have an etched slide ($12) that allowed me to calibrate my system at both 400x and 1000×. I then use Adobe Photoshop to crop down to a single spore, rotate it horizontally, and measure the number of pixels in length and width. At 400x, 19.28 pixels equal 1.0µm and at 1000x, 48.78 pixels equal 1.0µm. For example, if a length of one spore is 145 pixels (131 pixels/19.28 pixels/µm = 6.791µm).
To nerd it a bit more, I am including a graph of the length vs width of the spore measurement for this example.
Note: I had to generate the video at a low resolution to upload it easily. I marked each spore that I measured with a red rectangle so that I could avoid duplications.

results.notes:
Specimens were found growing in soil covered with wood chips in relatively new (within last year) urban landscaping. Specimens were consistently growing within inches of a transplanted Mahonia sp. shrubs, suggesting that spores may have come with those transplants.

Single-pictured specimen was about 10 cm in overall height, cap 6 cm high, 5 cm wide at widest point. Stipe off-white, hollow, and widens toward bottom. Cap predominantly light brown, dark brown on ridges. Approx 15 vertically-oriented ridges with ~12 horizontal, recessed ridges within each.

results.notes:
This was a mycoblitz candidate from last year. Sequence suggest a match to two X. cirris – both of which though are rather short sequences. (See Terri Clements Tree; MO377795)
These were NOT growing as a troop – but singles here and there.
In particularly unusual old growth forest; western red cedar, yellow cedar, Hemlock, silver fir.

The following was written at time it was submitted;
“Very tiny mushroom barely visible to the naked eye. Very wiry stipe that was strong and almost unbreakable. Interesting butterscotch colored rhizomes at base of stipe. Stipe very dark – almost purplish colored under hand lens.
The mushroom upon being placed in a cup of water expanded appreciably.”

results.notes:
Fruiting from Quercus wood. Subiculum is minimal, white and sparse, hyaline. Largest apothecium ~2mm but most smaller. Hairs ~15O um and septate. IKI +. Crozier +. Medullary excipulum textura intricata, closer to edge ectal more angularis. Paraphyses filiform, septate. 8-spored, ellipsoidal, mostly 3 septate but some only 1. Spores in H2O appear to have appendages but dissolve in 10% KOH or lactophenol blue.
Spore measure in H20:
(13.1) 16 – 20.5 (21.6) × (3.1) 3.6 – 4.2 (4.3) µm
Q = (3.6) 3.9 – 5.5 (5.8) ; N = 10
Me = 18 × 3.9 µm ; Qe = 4.7

Any help identifying these with these limited photos/info would be greatly appreciated!

notes_fields.Macro: This stinkhorn was spotted in our yard near Normanna, Texas yesterday as an “egg-shaped” growth after about an inch of recent slow rain. Overnight, it popped up as a fly-attracting stinkhorn and I collected it today. The top structure is a rough funnel shape with a hole leading to a hollow stipe. From the bottom of the funnel and wrapped around the top of the stipe, is a gooey, stinky, dark brown collar. The stipe is 15cm long and 2cm in diameter arising from a vulva half-buried in the soil. A remnant veil is attached 3cm above the top of the vulva. The stipe is a spongy off-white hollow structure. I believe it is in the Phallus genus and probably P. impudicus.
notes_fields.Micro: I was not successful at finding spores in either the collar or tissue of the cap.
notes_fields.Host: Two young Burr Oak Trees were nearby.

results.notes:
Same as seen here obs 404621 .

Discussion seen at obs 404621 mentions the possibility of there being several lichen species growing on the tree. We revisited this tree and found what appears to be two lichen species on this one oak (the other being a species of Physcia). Third photo down shows tree trunk with dark green lichen (this one), and blue-green lichen (we think Physcia). Also very close this oak tree there are hemlock twigs covered in Flavoparmeila caperata lying on the ground.

Micro is of material sliced from an apothecium (to the best of my ability), mounted in Congo red. Many of the long, thin, needle-shaped objects observed. These appear to fit the description of Bacidia schweinitzii spores, except the lengths of the ones seen here appear to routinely approach 90 microns (just beyond the upper limit of B. schweinitzii outliers). Viewed at 400x with my better scope (which does not yield good photos) these objects (spores?) appear to be septate with many (~20) septa. Segments appear to feature small one small circular object per segment.

Micro seen/described here does not mirror that seen in obs 404621. In this earlier observation (material from same tree), my attempt at microscopy was not very well focused (metaphorically speaking).

Other lichen on this same tree obs 405952. (Third photo down, the proposed Bacidia is dark green and the Physcia blue-green.) Also one same tree obs 405954. On hemlock twigs very near this tree obs 405951.

I had it described before here in previous observations, so I am not going to do it again now, other than adding a new comment about the short gills. In the reference mention above it says: “with 3-5 series of lamellula”. I have been looking for an explanation of that, and I haven’t found it. What I am observing is a pattern that repeats and looks like ..Short, Medium Length, short, Full length, short…(See picture with gill detail). Anyway, it has a distinct pattern. Is this a 3-5 series? Where can I find information on that?

notes_fields.Macro:
This morning, our flower bed sported more than a dozen small parasol-shaped mushrooms. Two hours after I discovered them (by mid-morning) they had deteriorated (wilted) badly and by noon, they could not be seen at all. I was able to collect a few specimens before they disappeared. As they progressed, there was a striking change in the gills, from feathery white to lined with black (see photo).
I measured the largest specimen to have a cap diameter of 2.0cm and a stem length of 4cm. My impression is that they belong in the genus Parasola, but from what I can see, the gills are not free (more seceding or sinuate) and it seems that all Parasola species have free gills. They were deteriorating so fast, that I decide to smash a small segment of the black gill edge on a microscope slide (hoping to get a few spores) and pop them in the dehydrator.
I don’t know what these are, but I’m guessing that they belong in Parasola. ID help would be appreciated.
notes_fields.Micro: Spore photo attached but spore may not be mature. I measured one of the larger spores to be 10.9µm x 7.3µm which is fairly large as my limited experience suggest.

results.notes: On red clay soil in open sunny location, potentially gets inundated periodically during rain storms. Thallus mottled green-grey, rarely with horizontal branching, cortex and medulla K-. Apothecia common, deeply immersed and erupting through thallus, with an epruinose disk, white crenate thalline margin. Epihymenium green, K- (not turning brown). Hymenium tall. Paraphyses somewhat branched, submoniliform. Asci with mostly immature spores and spore count was inconclusive but seemed to be less than 8. Spores large, subglobose, about 28×18µm.
